column4: When I type: 'ls "~/' without the single-quotes, and I press tab, bash no longer completes ~/ to /home/user, because it's in double quotes. Also, if I type 'ls "~/"' without double-quotes, ls and other programs don't understand what ~/ is because it's not getting expanded in double quotes. I think this has to do with /etc/bash_completion, any idea how to fix it?
i think that's actually the correct behaviour.
It's actually not.
The shell should be expanding ~ wherever it is.
i don't think so. surely you'd need a way to quote the thing?
It was like this in previous versions of ubuntu.
You do it with single-quotes '~'
Single-quotes imply literal, double quotes allow you to have expandable variables.
It's definitely the wrong behaviour.
we'll have to agree to disagree on that point.
All previous versions of Ubuntu, and Redhat both expand the way I'm talking about.
then run one of them
Try it in your shell right now and see what happens.
I bet it works on yours, mine is broken.
Either that or Ubuntu 7.04 is broken.
then  how did you break yours?
